bestBHT.bht: In this message, there is a urging to listen carefully to the message conveyed. The church in Thyatira symbolizes the church's broad presence and its interaction with the non-believing world. However, they have lost sight of their devotion to Jesus, who is always present and whose rewards are in the future. This verse underlines the significance of being receptive to this admonition, encouraging individuals to pay attention and heed its importance.

Albert Barnes: He that hath an ear ... - See the notes on Revelation 2:7.
Philip Schaff: In the church at Thyatira we seem to pass for the first time to the Church considered in her widest aspect and as brought into positive relations with the powers of the heathen world.
The first Epistle of the second group thus corresponds to the first of the first group, although with a difference in harmony with the general nature of the two groups as wholes.

In the one case she has forgotten Him who walketh in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks, and whose love never fails: in the other the power of the present and the seen has led too many of her members to break their covenant with Him who is the Son of God, whose kingdom is not of this world, and whose rewards are future and unseen.
John Gill: He that hath an ear, let him hear,....

bhtAttempts.bht: In Revelation 2:29, the verse directs the reader to refer to the commentary on verse 7. Expanding on the thoughts from the second-tier commentary, the church at Thyatira represents the wideness of the church and its engagement with the heathen world. While the first Epistle in this group corresponds to the first of the previous group, there is a difference in tone. The church in Thyatira has forgotten about the ever-present Christ and has been led astray by worldly powers. The verse emphasizes the need for those with an ear to hear this message.

In this passage, there is a call for attentive listening, as mentioned in the commentary. The church at Thyatira represents the broad reach of the church, but it has veered off the path. The church's allurements have caused its members to forsake their relationship with the Son of God, whose kingdom is beyond this world. The verse emphasizes the importance of having an open ear to receive this message, urging readers to pay heed.

In this message, there is a urging to listen carefully to the message conveyed. The church in Thyatira symbolizes the church's broad presence and its interaction with the non-believing world. However, they have lost sight of their devotion to Jesus, who is always present and whose rewards are in the future. This verse underlines the significance of being receptive to this admonition, encouraging individuals to pay attention and heed its importance.

The call to attentive listening is echoed in this message, prompting individuals to hear with discernment. The church in Thyatira embodies the expansive nature of the church and its engagement with the secular world. Nevertheless, they have strayed from their commitment to the Son of God, forsaking His future rewards for the allurements of the present. This passage emphasizes the crucial role of having receptive ears to internalize and apply this cautionary message.

The urgent plea to listen attentively fills this message, urging individuals to adhere closely. The Thyatira Church signifies the extensive reach of the church and its involvement with the unbelieving world. Yet, they have forgotten their allegiance to the Son of God, forgoing His eternal rewards in pursuit of earthly pleasures and influences. The verse emphasizes the necessity of receptive ears, imploring readers to grasp the significance of this warning and respond accordingly.
